Originally posted by wjim1269 
 Experimental evidence.
 
 
 
 So, if you were presented with a paper detailing observation of it in a tissue culture in a laboratory, would that be acceptable?

autosome 
 
 Inheritance and meiotic behaviour of a de novo chromosome fusion in the aphid Myzus persicae (Sulzer)
 Spence JM, Blackman RL
 CHROMOSOMA
 109 (7): 490-497 NOV 2000
 
 Document type: Article Language: English Cited References: 19 Times Cited: 2 
 
 Abstract:
 A de novo tandem fusion between autosomes 2 and 3 (A2+3), arising in the course of laboratory crosses of sexual morphs of two clones of the aphid Myzus persicae, was stable through more than 180 generations of parthenogenetic (clonal) reproduction. Studies of its inheritance through the sexual phase, and segregation from an amplified esterase marker gene, showed that crossing over occurred during oogenesis, but in in spermatogenesis, confirming previous cytological observations. Only a small number of progeny resulted from attempts at selfing fusion heterozygotes, and none of these was homozygous for the fusion. A2+3 paired in parallel alignment with the separate A2 and A3 to form a trivalent at prophase I of spermatogenesis. Fusion heterozygotes had a segregation problem at anaphase I of meiosis, A2+3 forming a chromatin bridge between the daughter spermatocytes in about 42% of dividing cells, which could be attributed to alternate orientation in the trivalent (A2 and A3 paired with opposite sides of A2+3) in the preceding metaphase I. Males heterozygous for an A2 dissociation were also studied and found to have much less of a segregation problem, despite showing similar orientation patterns at metaphase I. Possible reasons for this difference and the significance of the findings in relation to karyotype evolution in aphids are discussed.
In that case, I'm sorry for stating that it was spectulation. From what I had read in your post, it only looked like spectulation. I hadn't seen anything on that topic before.

Originally posted by wjim1269

Hmmmm......That's a new one.......I debated competitively for two years and I was never told that I was supposed to do your research for you.

Even when you are trying to argue a fact?
 
 Seems like your debate coach would have warned you about doing enough research to avoid basic errors.

#1) I argued against what you gave me. In competitive debate, you don't get second chances. You gave me speculative evidence, and I told you it was speculative. You then gave me harder evidence, but then told me I should have found during my research. No, I should not have found it; you should have presented it with the speculative evidence you presented.
 #2) This is not a competitive debate. I visit boards like these in my free time, and I don't have time to research for all subjects. I research for the subjects I am most interested in, and since creation vs. evolution is overall, a useless debate (see my first post in that forum on why I believe that), that has gotten none of my research time.
